lexUnit.name: seep.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: (of a liquid) flow or leak slowly through porous material or small holes.

sentence.text: The rest of the blood seeped away from Herr Nordern 's face , leaving it as white as his wife 's .
Blood was still seeping from Ray Shepherd 's shoulder , and near them , Steve was weeping and softly calling out his father 's name .
His trousers were ripped and the blood seeped down his leg from the gash inches above his knee .
Holman was hardly listening for he 'd noticed fresh blood seeping through the sheets .
A blade glinted , and as if by magic a crescent appeared on the man 's cheek , with little beads of blood seeping out like juice from an orange .
A third had a bloodstained rag bound round his forehead like a sweatband , from under which blood was seeping and trickling down the left side of his face .
An explosion of methane gas which seeped up from the ground in Derbyshire 5 years ago demolished a pensioner 's house .
The gas , which seeps out of the earth from underground uranium deposits , can collect in dangerous concentrations in some houses .
The possibility of salt water seeping into fresh-water tables carried heavy weight in the decision process .
A trickle of water seeping out from under the rocks had damped the red clay of which the track was composed , making an ideal surface for the impression of tracks .
If frosts freeze water that has seeped into imperfect joints , the expansion will force them farther apart , with disastrous results .
Joints open up , and crumbling putty allows water to seep in around the panes , eventually rotting the glazing bars and frame members .
Water was seeping through the walls and the wiring was in urgent need of replacement .

To reduce salt levels and assist evaporation , interior and exterior pebble-filled ditches have been dug around the church with perforated plastic pipes designed to collect salt-charged water seeping from the walls .
Blanketweed collecting on the waterfall may cause water to seep away from the pond itself .
A government report of Sept. 27 found that millions of litres of radioactive water were seeping out of leaky tanks at Kozloduy , which provided around 40 per cent of Bulgaria 's electricity .
The days when water authorities could allow their supplies to seep into the ground are definitely at an end .
Sticky pools and channels of drink were seeping out through the gaps in the floorboards on to the sand beneath the kiosk .
Keeping his gaze on the thread of light seeping out from the Bogeyman 's room , he inched his way along the threadbare strip of carpet .
Nonetheless , knowledge seeped out ; not least because both the Iran and contra operations , however much compartmented and closely held , were run by a man who could not resist talking about them .
Then he added , with a sudden burst of frankness , ` I reckoned the news would seep out anyway in time and cause them to lose plenty of sleep . "
A fat tear seeped out from under each of her eyelids , but she was too tired to wipe them away .
I had never been in the lift since moving -- either it was out of order or I could smell the putrid stench seeping out into the lobby and avoided it .
The painful tears seeped slowly from Hector 's bandage , and his grandfather reached out a trembling hand to wipe them away .
Blood-beads had seeped from tiny capillaries in the butterfly 's wings .
The black walls of an enormous sprawling house rose menacingly from the rank weeds and thorns and , as Cleo had noticed , a thin reed of smoke was seeping from one of the many narrow chimneys .
His ears popped and fluid seeped from his nose .
Overnight , a damp fog had seeped inland from the sea , hanging above the beach , clinging to the buildings .
Advice was hurled up at her , but smoke began seeping from the window behind the servant and she needed no urging .
I was comforted by the little natural light that seeped through the canvas .
Her tears seeped through the cotton mattress of her cot and fell onto the European stones .
He holds a soggy triangle of chips , the grease seeping through the paper .
The bedroom was dim , full of mist seeping through the windows and the candles spluttered and wavered in the draught .

If you live in London , yours could be the seventh pair of kidneys that your glass of water has passed through and chemicals used in farming today seep into the ground to pollute and contaminate the water .
She was still shivering when he finished , but the warmth gradually began to seep inwards to where her bones were chilled .
As he gazed up into the heights above he noticed a faint thickening of the air as if some of the mist had seeped inside .
Drop down a little and you 'll find a hotplate with four burners sealed to prevent spillage seeping underneath and removable supports for easy cleaning .
